Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Story: I glanced at the clock, my heart pounding. My daughter had called earlier, her voice bubbling with excitement—my grandson had won his first school award, and the family was gathering to celebrate. I could already picture his proud little face, the way he’d look for me in the crowd. I wanted nothing more than to be there, to clap the loudest, to hug him tight. But as I buttoned my uniform, the radio crackled: “All operators, mandatory pre-shift briefing in ten minutes. Attendance required. New safety protocols.” My supervisor’s tone left no room for negotiation. I knew the importance—lives depended on us following every rule, every update. Still, the thought of missing my grandson’s big moment gnawed at me. My family expected me to be present, to show I cared. My job demanded unwavering commitment, especially now. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between the world that needed me and the world that loved me, feeling the weight of both pressing in, waiting for me to choose.
